key_title: Key to the species of Digitaria

Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Spikelets densely silky-hairy on adaxial surface; panicle branches stiffly spreading; uncommon perennials of dry areas
Spikelets glabrous to shortly pubescent; panicle branches not stiff; annuals (or short-lived perennials) of disturbed or irrigated areas
Lower panicle branches whorled, devoid of spikelets in the lower 2 cm or more, widely spreading at maturity
Panicle branches not whorled, bearing spikelets virtually to base, remaining suberect at maturity
Spikelets 2–3 mm long; leaf margins strongly crimped
Spikelets 3–4.5 mm long; leaf margins plane or weakly undulate
Inflorescence not digitate, branches spaced along main axis; spikelets bearing short acute hairs (often obscure); native perennial
Inflorescence digitate or subdigitate; spikelets with club-shaped hairs; weedy annual
Inflorescence digitate, generally with 4–10 racemes; upper glume up to half as long as the  spikelet; common and widespread summer to early autumn-active weed
Inflorescence of 2 or 3 racemes (rarely more); upper glume as long as the spikelet; currently known from Mallacoota area only.
